name: Meson Sacristia de la Compania

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: A friend had read about this hotel in the travel section of the New York Times before our recent trip to Mexico last month, and so the four us (2 couples) decided to take a road trip to Puebla and stay here for a few days. This place exceeded all of my expectations. Each room is uniquely designed and is decorated with antiques, Mexican crafts, and tile and ceramic work which the state of Puebla is known for, which are all available for sale. There were little pieces of history throughout the hotel; in fact the heavy wooden door to our bathroom supposedly originated from an old colonial jail. I opted for a honeymoon suite, which had a balcony that overlooked a cobblestone avenue lined with colonial buildings. At sunset the entire street would be cast in an orange glow, as the bells from the Catedral nearby rang and echoed. I loved that this hotel has it's own personality and spirit, as I am not a fan of large corporate hotels where every room looks the same.
reviews.title: A place with soul and character

reviews.text: The staff was more than accommodating (and extremely patient) with us. Our first night there, we didn't feel like going to a bar, so we just bought some beer and drank in our suite and listened to music. As the night progressed and we ran out of beer, we asked the bell hop if there was a store nearby that was still open where we could purchase some more. He offered to go buy the beer FOR us. They were also extremely patient with us when we woke up late on the day of our departure and didn't check out until after the appointed check out time (a corporate hotel would have nailed us with a charge, or charged us for another night entirely for being late). Since we got the honeymoon suite, our package included breakfast, and I loved the chilaquiles with verde sauce. My only regret is that I didn't try the mole here at dinner time (which is what the hotel is also famous for).
reviews.title: We absolutuely loved everything at Meson Sacristia

reviews.text: My sister and I stayed at Meson Sacristia for one week, Nov. 5-12. We were very pleased with the decor ( lots of colonial antiques and art), the room (large with balcony overlooking street), the food (just great and authentic poblana cuisine), the service (the front desk and concierge), and most of all the cooking lessons (5 day series). We loved the cooking lessons with chef Alonso Hernandez and public relations assistant Isis Moreno - we learned to cook everything from mole poblana to arroz con leche, and then we got to eat our masterpieces for lunch everyday. The location of the Meson was also great because it was right in the center of Puebla, only 2 blocks from the Zocalo (main plaza), artist neighborhood, and on the same street as great antique stores.
reviews.title: Cook like a Mexican!

reviews.text: Jerry and I decided to try something new and different for our Thanksgiving holiday, so we chose a cooking class in Puebla. Not knowing what to really expect, we were pleasantly surprised at the organization of the week-long classes, the patience and genuine friendliness of the chef and assistant, and their expertise and skill in teaching the cooking classes and their knowledge of the origins and evolution of the particular dishes that were taught.
reviews.title: Beautiul little hotel with Big charm

likes.liked: — Friendly staff & close to town & shopping
likes.disliked: — Hot water system only enough for one person

reviews.text: We stayed for 5 days and opted for the "Meeting Puebla" package which included most meals, and several tours/activities. The reception desk staff, and Isis, who handled the arrangements, were very friendly and helpful. A few nights were a little noisy due to a next-door bar but with the windows shut it was manageable. The hotel had already prepared us not to expect AC or perfect plumbing/showers so it wasn't a big deal when occasionally the toilet was slow or the shower water pressure low. The food in the restaurant was excellent and the menu large (much more to choose from than the sister hotel, meson sacristia capuchinas).
reviews.title: Trip to Puebla

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Of the activities, the cooking class and Talavera pottery class were great. The city tour of Puebla was also very good. We were less thrilled by the trips to Cholula and to Cuetzalan. The only issue with the trip to Cholula was that the scheduled time should have been earlier in the day. We were given the option of either walking to the top of the ruins/church, or going through the underground tunnels but not both since our guide told us the tunnels were going to close before we came down from the top.
reviews.title: The Meson Sacristia is great, so is Puebla!

likes.liked: — Friendly staff, quaint digs, good location.

reviews.title: Great artistic vacation
reviews.text: Regarding Cuetzalan, I would forgo it entirely if traveling on a day-trip from Puebla. The trip there took us 5 hours with 3 of us in a very cramped back seat of a car (less room than on the worst airplane imaginable), while we got lost several times and the guide and driver spoke nearly non-stop to each other in Spanish. The return trip took about 4 hours. Although it is interesting to see a small mountain town, particularly if you haven't seen this type of place before, it wasn't worth more than 9 hours in the car. Also, while we ate lunch in the town, there was a continuous stream of people coming in to the restaurant trying very persistently to sell us things. This became annoying after a short time, particularly since we were inside as opposed to sitting at table on the street, but no attempt was made by the restaurant staff or the guide to discourage the parade.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: If not for the Cuetzalan experience, I would have rated the experience as excellent.
reviews.title: fantastic concierge service and ambience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This property is a hoot! We stayed here two nights. Very tricky to find in a rental car, but not impossible! It really is located in the Alley of the Toads, a tiny, oneway, half block alley, about 3 blocks off the main square of Puebla. A very small property, I think 8 rooms, but filled with Colonial antiques and bright pink and blue walls.
reviews.title: Fun cooking classes, great city, beautiful hotel!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We just spent a week at this great hotel. We had five days of cooking classes with Chef Alonso Hernandez and Isis Moreno Cosme, the hotels Public Relations Sub Manager who assisted as a translator. If you are interested in a fun and informational class on basic Mexican cooking, this is for you. It was hands on and we sat down and ate the food for lunch each day. You can arrange classes teh three hour classes for one day to five days. We even went to the market one day.
reviews.title: Beautiful Hotel and Staff

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: As stated in other reviews, this is a quaint boutique hotel in an 250-year-old building decorated with Colonial-era antiques. Thus some of the bathrooms can be a little small, but you can find that anywhere in the world where older buildings have been converted to hotels. What makes this one special is the staff. Everyone at the front desk and restaurant was extremely nice and helpful.
reviews.title: outstanding!!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Isis Moreno Cosme was a valuable resource for information, helping with reservations and tours. Whether you are interested in cooking classes or not, there is much to do each day like taking a city tour, visiting a Talavera factory, visiting one the many museums (especially the Ampora Museum), or arranging a trip to the great pyramid at Cholula. All of this can be done through the hotel. We also used the services of a local guide, Carlos Rivero who has a web site.
reviews.title: Great service but not so great hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: For us, this was a perfect trip. Puebla is a beautiful Mexican Colonial city not to be missed. Check out the hotel's web site for great package deals.

aka: Meson Sacristia De La Compania Hotel
description: From the outside, this hotel looks like a simple colonial building with typical Spanish terraces and heavy wooden doors. Once you enter the courtyard, you are instantly transported back to 19h century Mexico. The décor is an eclectic blend of beautifully preserved colonial antiques and rustic furniture. Each room is uniquely decorated with antique and, if you like what you see, you can buy the whole ensemble and take it home! How so? At Mesón Sacristía de la Compañia you can also immerse yourself in Mexico through cooking classes or hands –on pottery courses either one a memorable souvenir. The award-winning hotel restaurants is the place to experience true Pueblan food, served in the courtyard, made even richer by live traditional music nightly. Experience colonial Mexico and enjoy exemplary Pueblan service and hospitality.
